pageData.text: In this investigation, students will examine a model of the human skeleton and identify bones, together with their most prominent surface features. Students will identify various types of joints and the movements associated with many of them. Using twine and tape, students will model the <button class='glossary-text'>origins</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>insertions</button>, and <button class='glossary-text'>actions</button> of selected skeletal muscles.

pageData.text: The musculoskeletal system is responsible for the incredible range of movement of the human body: a student typing on a keyboard, an athlete executing a jump, a student reaching for a high bookshelf. The joints of the skeleton allow for different types of movement between bones, while different skeletal muscles facilitate that movement. The study of such form and function in the human body is important in fields such as athletics, occupational therapy, and even the arts.

For centuries, artists have studied the form and movement of the human body to improve their works. An artistic rendering of a human subject appears realistic when its proportions are accurate, and its form feels the weight of gravity. Ancient artists would study the movement and external form of the body; eventually artists used dissection to better understand human anatomy, especially during the Renaissance. For example, renown Renaissance artist Leonardo da Vinci dissected a self-proclaimed 30 human cadavers during his lifetime. Understanding the bones of the skeleton, how they are connected to one another, and how they provide movement gives artists, then and now, the tools to create exceptionally realistic works of art.

pageData.desc: The sculpture Psyche Revived by Cupid's Kiss by Antonio Canova.
pageData.altText: The sculpture Psyche Revived by Cupid's Kiss by Antonio Canova.

pageData.text: Made up of bone and <button class='glossary-text'>cartilage</button>, the human skeletal system has many important functions, including support, movement, protection of internal organs, blood cell production, and mineral storage.

pageData.altText: Human Body: Digestive System

pageData.subTitle: Skeleton
pageData.text: The adult human body has 206 bones and can be divided into 2 parts—the <button class='glossary-text'>axial skeleton</button> and the <button class='glossary-text'>appendicular skeleton</button>.
The axial skeleton includes bones of the skull, , , , , and , totaling 80 bones.
The appendicular skeleton includes the 126 bones of the shoulders, <button class='glossary-text'>pelvis</button>, and upper and lower extremities.

pageData.subTitle: Bone Tissue
pageData.text: There are 2 types of bone tissue. Compact bone is hard, dense, mineralized tissue that gives bone its strength. It usually surrounds spongy bone tissue. Spongy bone is a porous layer of tissue that makes bone lightweight. Its spaces usually contain blood vessels and bone marrow, a soft tissue that produces blood cells.

pageData.subTitle: Cartilage
pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Cartilage</button> is a flexible connective tissue that forms the embryonic skeleton. Most is ossified into bone during fetal and childhood development. In adults, cartilage is found at movable joints, and in the ear, nose, trachea, and other structures. It also connects the ribs and sternum.

pageData.subTitle: The Skeletal System
pageData.text: The human skeletal system includes 206 individual bones plus associated connective tissues, including <button class='glossary-text'>cartilage</button>, which provides flexible support and protection; <button class='glossary-text'>tendons</button>, which join muscle to bone; and <button class='glossary-text'>ligaments</button>, which join bones to other bones. The skeleton functions to:

1. Support the body—The skeleton is the body’s internal, weight-bearing framework. Bone tissue is a specialized type of connective tissue, given strength by a dense network of collagen fibers and rigidity by a mineralized matrix.
  2. Protect organs—Vulnerable internal organs—such as the brain, spinal cord, and heart and lungs—are protected by the bones of the , , and ribcage, respectively.
  3. Store minerals and fats—Bone serves as a reservoir for important minerals, such as calcium and phosphorus. Fat is stored in the marrow of many bones.
  4. Generate blood cells—All types of blood cells originate from stem cells residing in the bone marrow. The differentiated progeny of these stem cells are eventually released into the bloodstream.
1. Provide leverage for movement—When skeletal muscles contract, they exert pulling force on bones of the skeleton, which serve as . In this way, body movements are generated.

feedbackData.title: Feedback

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The human skeleton performs many functions. Structures like the skull and ribcage protect soft, vital organs; the organization of the muscles and bones together supports the body and allows it to move; the internal structure of the bones facilitates the storage of nutrients and the synthesis of blood cells. These functions are essential in sustaining the human body.

pageData.text: This investigation begins with a survey of the bones of the human skeleton and their major surface features. Bones come in a wide variety of shapes that reflect their functions in the musculoskeletal system. For convenience, they may be classified as belonging to one of five basic types:

1. —The length of the bone is greater than its width, and both ends are expanded (see Figure 1).
  2. —The bone is relatively thin and flat, like a plate.
  3. —The bone is notably uneven in shape.
  4. —The length and width of the bone are roughly the same, making the shape somewhat cubelike.
  5. —The bone is embedded in a at a joint.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Anatomy of a long bone
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Anatomy of a long bone

pageData.text: A typical has a slender, elongated region called the , or shaft, with expanded ends called epiphyses (singular, ), as shown in . The epiphysis closest to the center of the body is the , and that at the opposite end of the bone is the . The region between the diaphysis and each epiphysis is known as a (plural, metaphyses). Between the epiphysis and metaphysis is the , the remnant of the epiphyseal plate where the bone grew in length throughout childhood. The space within the diaphysis is called the . In a living long bone of the adult human skeleton, this space is filled with , a type of bone marrow that is rich in fat cells. The epiphyses of certain long bones contain , in which stem cells that generate blood cells reside. Red marrow is also found within the of the skeleton.

pageData.text: Activities 1-5 will guide you through most of the bones of the adult human skeleton. As you work through these activities, you will encounter examples of all five bone shapes. In addition, you will see a number of surface characteristics. These include openings for the passage of blood vessels and nerves, points of attachment for <button class='glossary-text'>ligaments</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>tendons</button>, and regions that come together with adjacent bones to form <button class='glossary-text'>articulations</button> (joints). The most commonly used terms for the description of skeletal surface features are listed in <button class='resource-text'>Table 1</button>.

tableData.text: Curved prominence at the end of a bone
Narrow projecting ridge, often on border of bone
Passage for nerves and blood vessels
Rounded projection at one end of long bone
Narrow portion of long bone that connects head to diaphysis
Narrow projecting ridge, typically more prominent than a crest

pageData.text: Activity 6 is an exploration of the various <button class='glossary-text'>articulations</button> of the human skeleton, which can be described in terms of their mobility and their structure. There are three functional classes of articulation based on the degree to which the bones move:

1. are immoveable joints, such as the that join the bones of the .
  2. are slightly moveable joints, such as those between the vertebrae.
  3. are freely moveable joints, such as the knee.
There are three different structural types of articulations:

1. —The bones are joined with dense connective tissue, and the joint is immoveable or slightly moveable. The cranial sutures are fibrous joints.
  2. —The bones are joined with (fibrocartilage or hyaline cartilage), and the joint may be slightly but not freely moveable. The intervertebral joints are cartilaginous.
1. —The hyaline cartilage-covered ends of the bones are separated by a filled with lubricating synovial fluid produced by a ; the joint is freely moveable, like the knee.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Articulations, or joints, of the human skeleton are categorized into three different functional classes. These classes are defined by the degree to which the bones in the articulation move. Synarthoses, such as the sutures connecting cranial bones, are immovable joints; amphiarthoses, such as the joints between vertebrae, are slightly moveable; diarthoses, such as finger or knee joints, are freely moveable.

pageData.subTitle: The Muscular System
pageData.text: There are about 640 skeletal muscles in the human body. Each skeletal muscle is an organ composed of skeletal (or voluntary) muscle; connective tissue, including vascular (blood) tissue; and nervous tissue, which receives input from the central nervous system to stimulate muscular contraction. Skeletal muscles and their associated tendons also contain sensory nervous structures that send messages about changes in muscle length or tension back toward the central nervous system. The muscular system consists of contractile muscle tissue and the tendons that connect skeletal muscles to bones or other structures on which the muscles will exert force. The skeletal and muscular systems work together to generate body movements; thus, together they are considered the musculoskeletal system.

pageData.subTitle: The Musculoskeletal System
pageData.text: A is a moveable, rigid bar. The fixed point on which a lever moves when force is applied is called a . In the skeleton, bones that serve as levers and moveable joints are fulcrums. The contraction of attached muscles provides the force needed to achieve movement. Figure 2 is a diagram of the human arm. The bones of the forearm (lower arm) serve as the rigid bar or lever. The elbow joint is the fulcrum (F ). The muscle shown (the biceps) provides the effort (E ), or force when it contracts and pulls against its point of attachment to the bone, and the weight of the forearm and hand (including objects held in the hand) is the resistance (R ) to be lifted.

pageData.desc: Figure 2: Diagram depicting the human arm as a biological lever
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Diagram depicting the human arm as a biological lever

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes how the force to achieve body movement is generated?

options.text: Bones, attached to other bones, contract.
Muscles, attached to joints, meet resistance.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Muscles can move the bones to which they are attached when they contract.

pageData.question: Which of the following terms best describes the force with which muscles create body movement?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Muscles exert contractile force. In the case of skeletal muscles, this creates body movement. The contraction of other muscle types creates involuntary movement of internal organs.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The musculoskeletal system is made up of muscle tissue connected to bones or other structures by tendons. When these muscles contract, or tighten, they exert force on the structures to which they are connected, creating body movements.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The musculoskeletal system is made up of muscle tissue connected to bones or other structures by tendons. When these muscles contract, or tighten, they exert force on the structures to which they are connected, creating body movements.

pageData.text: Each skeletal muscle can be described in terms of its <button class='glossary-text'>origin</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>insertion</button>, and <button class='glossary-text'>action</button>.

text: The origin is the bone to which the muscle is attached that has the greater mass and stability during contraction. It is typically the more proximal (closer to the body’s midline or center) point of attachment.

The insertion is the bone or other point of attachment (such as a <button class='glossary-text'>tendon</button> or other connective tissue) that tends to move the greatest distance when the muscle contracts. The muscle insertion is typically less massive and more distal (farther from the body’s midline or center) than the origin.
The action of a muscle is the movement that results when the muscle contracts.

pageData.text: Figure 3 illustrates two skeletal muscles, the biceps and triceps, together with their and . The biceps muscle of the upper arm is attached by two origins (and therefore has two ) to the bone in the shoulder (also known as the shoulder blade). The biceps runs the length of the bone in the upper arm and is attached to the bone of the forearm (lower arm) at its . The forearm is formed by two bones: the radius and the . The triceps muscle of the upper arm is attached by three origins (and therefore three heads)—one to the scapula and two to the humerus. (Note that in Figure 3, the third triceps origin is indicated but not visible.) The triceps runs the length of the humerus on the underside of the upper arm and attaches to the ulna bone of the forearm at its insertion.When skeletal muscles contract, the insertion is pulled toward the stationary origin, causing bones to move at a joint. It is important to note that muscles act by exerting a pulling force, never a pushing force. Contracted muscles are shorter and thicker than when they are relaxed. When the biceps contracts, the arm bends at the elbow joint as the insertion on the forearm is pulled toward the origin on the shoulder blade. The biceps muscle is called a because it flexes, or bends, the elbow joint. The triceps muscle works in opposition to the biceps. When the triceps contracts, the insertion is pulled away from the origin, causing the arm to straighten, or extend, at the elbow. The triceps is therefore an muscle.

pageData.desc: Figure 3: Origins and insertions of the biceps and triceps muscles of the upper arm
pageData.altText: Figure 3: Origins and insertions of the biceps and triceps muscles of the upper arm

pageData.question: An extensor muscle is contracting. Which of the following best describes the origin and insertion of the muscle relative to one another during the contraction?

options.text: The insertion is pulled away from the origin.
The origin is pulled away from the insertion.
The insertion is pulled toward the origin.
The origin is pulled toward the insertion.
The origin and insertion do not move.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: When an extensor muscle contracts, the insertion is pulled away from the origin. This causes extension of the associated joint.

pageData.question: A flexor muscle is contracting. Which of the following best describes the origin and insertion of the muscle relative to one another during the contraction?

options.text: The insertion is pulled toward the origin.
The origin is pulled away from the insertion.
The insertion is pulled away from the origin.
The origin is pulled toward the insertion.
The origin and insertion do not move.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: When a flexor muscle contracts, the insertion is pulled toward the origin. This causes flexion of the associated joint.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Flexor muscles and extensor muscles behave differently when they contract. A flexor muscle, such as the biceps muscle, pulls the insertion on the forearm toward the origin on the shoulder blade; this causes the joint to flex or bend. On the other hand, an extensor muscle, such as the triceps muscle, pulls the insertion on the forearm away from the origin on the shoulder blade; this causes the arm to extend, or straighten, at the elbow.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Flexor muscles and extensor muscles behave differently when they contract. A flexor muscle, such as the biceps muscle, pulls the insertion on the forearm toward the origin on the shoulder blade; this causes the joint to flex or bend. On the other hand, an extensor muscle, such as the triceps muscle, pulls the insertion on the forearm away from the origin on the shoulder blade; this causes the arm to extend, or straighten, at the elbow.

pageData.text: The biceps and triceps flank the upper arm and work as an <button class='glossary-text'>antagonistic muscle pair</button> across the elbow joint. That is, when one contracts (the <button class='glossary-text'>agonist</button>), the contraction is modulated by the opposing simultaneous <button class='glossary-text'>action</button> of the other (the <button class='glossary-text'>antagonist</button>). (However, antagonists are not usually active when the agonist is contracting.) <button class='glossary-text'>Flexors</button> (like the biceps) are antagonists of <button class='glossary-text'>extensors</button> (like the triceps) and vice versa. Movement produced by contraction of the biceps muscle and “relaxation” of the triceps can be reversed by contraction of the triceps muscle and “relaxation” of the biceps. Other movable bones of the skeleton are also flanked by antagonistic skeletal muscle pairs, or muscle groups, to control body movements across joints.

The focus of Activity 7 is on the <button class='glossary-text'>origins</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>insertions</button>, and actions of selected skeletal muscles. You will notice that many names of individual muscles describe their origin, insertion, and/or action.

pages.title: Activity 1
pages.pageTitle:
A
  Overview of Axial and Appendicular Skeletal Structures

pageData.text: The human skeleton is divided into two sets of structures (see Figure 4). The corresponds roughly to the midline of the body and is composed of the skull, hyoid (not shown), , ribs, and . (In Figure 4, the axial skeleton is labeled on the left side of the figure in green.) The corresponds to the limbs, or appendages, and is composed of the bones of the arms, hands, fingers, legs, feet, and toes plus the structures that connect the limbs to the axial skeleton. (In Figure 4, the appendicular skeleton is labeled on the right side of the figure in red.) The consists of the and scapulae (shoulder blades) and joins the arms to the axial skeleton. The consists of the (singular, os coxae), or hip bones, which join the legs to the axial skeleton.

Identify the bones of the axial skeleton and the appendicular skeleton on your model of a human skeleton from both the anterior and posterior views. Use Figure 4 for reference. Be sure that you can confidently distinguish between these two divisions of the skeleton before proceeding to Activity 2.
As you proceed through Activities 1–5, find at least one example of each of the five different classifications of bone based on shape. For each example, take a photograph.

pageData.text: In Activity 2 you will identify the bones of the skull using the human skeleton model.
During this activity, continue your search for at least one example of each of the five different classifications of bone based on shape. For each example, take a photograph.

The skull is composed of two main sets of bones. Those of the <button class='glossary-text'>cranium</button> form a protective dome or vault that encases the brain. There are eight bones in the <button class='glossary-text'>cranium</button>: two pairs and four single bones. Identify them on your model using Figure 5 as a guide, taking careful note of any special features that are mentioned.

text: <button class='glossary-text'>Frontal bone</button>: This bone is the most anterior part of the cranium. It forms the forehead and the superior portion of the <button class='glossary-text'>orbits</button> (the cuplike depressions in which the eyeballs are located). Notice that above each orbit is a small opening called the <button class='glossary-text'>supraorbital foramen</button>. In a living body, blood vessels and nerves would pass through this opening.
<button class='glossary-text'>Parietal bones</button>: The paired parietal bones lie posterior to the frontal bone and comprise the right and left sides of the cranium.

<button class='glossary-text'>Temporal bones</button>: The paired temporal bones lie inferior to the parietal bones and make up the lateral aspect of the cranium. Notice that each has an opening, called the <button class='glossary-text'>external auditory meatus</button>, commonly known as the ear canal. Posterior and inferior to the external auditory meatus is a prominence called the <button class='glossary-text'>mastoid process</button>. (You can feel your own mastoid process by pressing just posterior and inferior to your ear.) It serves as a point of attachment for certain skeletal muscles of the head, neck, and back.

pageData.desc: Figure 5: Locations and names of the bones of the skull, from lateral and frontal viewpoints
pageData.altText: Figure 5: Locations and names of the bones of the skull, from lateral and frontal viewpoints

text: <button class='glossary-text'>Occipital bone</button>: This is the most posterior bone of the <button class='glossary-text'>cranium</button>. The <button class='glossary-text'>external occipital protuberance</button> projects from near the center of the occipital bone.
<button class='glossary-text'>Sphenoid bone</button>: The posterior region of each <button class='glossary-text'>orbit</button> is composed largely of sphenoid bone.

<button class='glossary-text'>Ethmoid bone</button>: The ethmoid makes up the roof of the nasal cavity, the superior part of the <button class='glossary-text'>nasal septum</button>, and the medial portion of each orbit. It has lateral and inferior projections called the <button class='glossary-text'>superior</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>middle nasal conchae</button> that are important in routing airflow in the nasal cavity.

pageData.text: The bones of the cranium <button class='glossary-text'>articulate</button> with one another at <button class='glossary-text'>synarthoses</button> called <button class='glossary-text'>sutures</button>. These are <button class='glossary-text'>fibrous joints</button> in which the edges of the cranial bones interlock with one another, similar to pieces of a jigsaw puzzle. Short connective tissue fibers join the bones at the sutures. Locate these major sutures of the cranium on your model, using <button class='resource-text'>Figure 5</button> as a guide.

text: <button class='glossary-text'>Sagittal suture</button>: This is where the two <button class='glossary-text'>parietal bones</button> <button class='glossary-text'>articulate</button> with one another, at the superior midline of the cranium. (These are not visible in Figure 5.)
<button class='glossary-text'>Coronal suture</button>: At this suture, the two parietal bones articulate with the <button class='glossary-text'>frontal bone</button>.
<button class='glossary-text'>Squamosal sutures</button>: Each of these two sutures is the articulation of a parietal bone with a temporal bone.
<button class='glossary-text'>Lambdoid suture</button>: This is where the two parietal bones articulate with the occipital bone.
<button class='glossary-text'>Occipitomastoid sutures</button>: These two sutures occur where the posterior and inferior region of each temporal bone articulates with the occipital bone.

pageData.text: There are 14 <button class='glossary-text'>facial bones</button> in the skull: six pairs and two single bones. Identify them, using <button class='resource-text'>Figure 5</button> as a guide, and taking careful note of any special features that are mentioned.

text: : This fused pair of maxilla bones makes up the upper jaw and contributes to the medial and inferior regions of the . Each maxilla articulates with nine other bones—the frontal and of the and the palatine, zygomatic, , nasal, , and inferior nasal concha of the face. For this reason, the maxillae are often referred to as the “keystone bones” of the face. The maxillae, along with the , are the tooth-bearing bones. Inferior to each orbit is an opening in the maxilla called an , which, in a living body, serves as a passageway for blood vessels and nerves.

Mandible: The lower jawbone articulates with the temporal bone in the only diarthosis of the skull, the . Like the maxillae, the mandible is a tooth-bearing bone. A tooth secured in its bony socket with fibrous connective tissue represents a specialized type of synarthosis called a (plural, gomphoses). Notice the two small lateral openings in the mandible. These are the . Each mental foramen serves as a passageway for nerves and blood vessels in a living body. The forms the chin.

Palatine: To view the paired palatine bones, open the jaws of your model and look at the roof of the mouth. Together with the palatine processes of the maxillae (which cannot be distinguished from the palatine bones on your model), the palatine bones form the hard palate and contribute to the floor of each orbit.
Zygomatic: Each lies lateral to a maxilla. The zygomatic bones are commonly known as the cheekbones. They also contribute to the lateral portion of each orbit.

<button class='glossary-text'>Lacrimal</button>: The lacrimals are very small bones located in the medial region of each orbit. Each lacrimal bone has an opening called a lacrimal fossa, which, in a living body, provides a passageway for a nasolacrimal duct (tear duct).
Nasal: The paired form the bridge of the nose.

: This unpaired bone (which is not depicted in your model) is medially situated within the nasal cavity. It serves as the posterior and inferior part of the . The name of the bone comes from the Latin term for plowshare and reflects its distinctive shape.

<button class='glossary-text'>Inferior nasal conchae</button>: These two curved bones (also called the inferior turbinates) form the lateral walls of the nasal cavity and extend projections medially, serving to agitate incoming air. As the air circulates within the nasal cavity, it is warmed and moistened, and particulate matter becomes trapped in the nasal epithelium.

pageData.text: In Activity 3 you will identify the bones of the <button class='glossary-text'>vertebral column</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>thoracic cage</button> using the human skeleton model.
During this activity, continue your search for at least one example of each of the five different classifications of bone based on shape. For each example, take a photograph.

pages.title: Activity 3
pages.pageTitle:
A
  The Axial Skeleton—The Vertebral Column and Thoracic Cage

pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>vertebral column</button>, also known as the spine or backbone, is a set of 26 bones extending from the base of the skull to the <button class='glossary-text'>pelvis</button>. It encloses and protects the spinal cord, which exits the base of the skull through a large opening called the <button class='glossary-text'>foramen magnum</button>. The vertebral column also supports the <button class='glossary-text'>head</button>, neck, and torso and provides numerous points of attachment for skeletal muscles.

The most numerous bones in the vertebral column are the 24 vertebrae, shown laterally in Figure 6. There are 7 in the neck, 12 in the upper back, and 5 in the lower back. The first cervical vertebra, also known as the , is named after a mythical giant who was said to carry the world on his shoulders. The second cervical vertebra is called the because it serves as the pivot on which the atlas rotates when you turn your head from side to side as if indicating “no.” (In f-h, you can see other movements of the head and neck that are enabled by the joint between the axis and the as well as the other cervical vertebrae.)

pageData.desc: Figure 6: Lateral view of the spinal column
pageData.altText: Figure 6: Lateral view of the spinal column

pageData.text: In a living body, the vertebrae are separated from one another by fluid-filled fibrocartilaginous discs called <button class='glossary-text'>intervertebral discs</button>. Thus, the joints between the vertebrae are considered <button class='glossary-text'>cartilaginous joints</button>. Because they are only slightly moveable, they are <button class='glossary-text'>amphiarthoses</button>. The gel-like fluid inside the intervertebral disc enables it to act as a “shock absorber” to protect the spine. The tough fibrocartilage exterior of the disc allows it to resist compression.

Inferior to the last lumbar vertebra is the <button class='glossary-text'>sacrum</button>, and inferior to the sacrum is the <button class='glossary-text'>coccyx</button>, also known as the tailbone. The sacrum and coccyx are composite bones, formed by the fusion of smaller, individual bones during development. The coccyx is an important attachment point for muscles and ligaments, and helps bear the body’s weight when sitting.

The is composed of the ribs, , and (see Figure 7, frontal view). It protects the heart, lungs, and other soft organs of the thoracic cavity. The flat sternum (commonly called the breastbone) is actually a composite bone with three components. The main portion is called the ; superior to the body is the , and inferior to the body is the pointed . Twelve pairs of ribs articulate posteriorly with the twelve thoracic vertebrae, but not all ribs articulate with the sternum. The superior seven pairs of ribs, known as the , articulate anteriorly with the sternum by means of composed of hyaline . Below these, three pairs of articulate with the costal cartilages located just above them. At the inferior region of the thoracic cage are two pairs of (or floating ribs) that have no anterior articulation at all. The vertebrocostal and vertebral ribs are sometimes referred to as false ribs, and the vertebrosternal ribs as true ribs.

pageData.desc: Figure 7: Frontal view of the right side of the thoracic cage
pageData.altText: Figure 7: Frontal view of the right side of the thoracic cage

pageData.text: In Activity 4 you will identify the bones of the <button class='glossary-text'>pectoral girdle</button> and upper limbs using the human skeleton model.
During this activity, continue your search for at least one example of each of the five different classifications of bone based on shape. For each example, take a photograph.

pages.title: Activity 4
pages.pageTitle:
A
  The Appendicular Skeleton—The Pectoral Girdle and Upper Limb

pageData.text: The left and right serve to attach the arms to the by means of attached skeletal muscles. A pectoral girdle is made up of two bones: a and a (see ). Figure 8 shows superior and inferior views of the left . The clavicle, commonly known as the collarbone (see Figure 8), articulates anteriorly with the manubrium of the (see ) and posteriorly with the scapula.

pageData.desc: Figure 8: Superior and inferior views of the left clavicle
pageData.altText: Figure 8: Superior and inferior views of the left clavicle

pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>scapula</button>, commonly known as the shoulder blade, is a wing-shaped bone. (The left scapula is shown in Figure 9 from posterior and lateral viewpoints.) The scapula has two major processes. The <button class='glossary-text'>coracoid process</button> is an important point of attachment for key muscles of the arm. The <button class='glossary-text'>acromion</button>, which is an extension of the posterior scapular spine, articulates with the <button class='glossary-text'>clavicle</button>. On either side of the spine is a shallow depression, or fossa. The superior depression is the <button class='glossary-text'>supraspinatous fossa</button>, and the inferior depression is the <button class='glossary-text'>infraspinatous fossa</button>. The flattened anterior side of the scapula features the <button class='glossary-text'>subscapular fossa</button>. The <button class='glossary-text'>glenoid cavity</button> articulates with the <button class='glossary-text'>humerus</button> as shown in <button class='resource-text'>Figure 4</button>. The supraglenoid tubercle is the small projection just superior to the glenoid cavity.

pageData.desc: Figure 9: Posterior and lateral views of the left scapula
pageData.altText: Figure 9: Posterior and lateral views of the left scapula

pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>humerus</button> is the only bone of the upper arm. The left humerus is shown from an anterior view in Figure 10. Its proximal <button class='glossary-text'>head</button> fits into the <button class='glossary-text'>glenoid cavity</button> of the <button class='glossary-text'>scapula</button>. On its proximal end, the laterally located <button class='glossary-text'>greater tubercle</button> and the medially located <button class='glossary-text'>lesser tubercle</button> are separated from one another by a depression called the <button class='glossary-text'>intertubercular groove</button>. The <button class='glossary-text'>tendon</button> of the biceps brachii muscle passes from its point of attachment adjacent to the glenoid cavity and along the intertubercular groove. Just distal to the head of the humerus is the <button class='glossary-text'>anatomical neck</button>, which in a living body is attached to the capsule of the <button class='glossary-text'>glenohumeral joint</button> (shoulder joint). Just distal to the anatomical neck is the <button class='glossary-text'>surgical neck</button>, a common site of fracture for this bone. The <button class='glossary-text'>deltoid tuberosity</button> is an important surface feature that serves as a site of attachment for the deltoid muscle. The distal end of the humerus features two points of articulation: the <button class='glossary-text'>trochlea</button>, which meets the <button class='glossary-text'>ulna</button> of the forearm and is flanked medially by a prominence called the <button class='glossary-text'>medial epicondyle</button> and the <button class='glossary-text'>capitulum</button>, which articulates with the <button class='glossary-text'>head</button> of the <button class='glossary-text'>radius</button> and is flanked laterally by a prominence called the <button class='glossary-text'>lateral epicondyle</button>. Just above the trochlea and capitulum is a depression called the <button class='glossary-text'>coronoid fossa</button>, which accommodates the ulna during movements at the elbow.

pageData.desc: Figure 10: Anterior view of the left humerus
pageData.altText: Figure 10: Anterior view of the left humerus

pageData.text: As mentioned in the “Background” of this investigation, the forearm contains two <button class='glossary-text'>long bones</button>: the <button class='glossary-text'>radius</button> and the larger <button class='glossary-text'>ulna</button>. Figure 11 depicts the anterior of the left radius and ulna. Re-examine <button class='resource-text'>Figure 4</button> and notice that, when the arm is in the standard anatomical position with the palm facing forward like the left forearm of the skeleton in the figure, the radius and ulna are oriented parallel to one another, with the radius lateral to the ulna. However, the radius can rotate around the ulna when the arm is rotated, as seen in the right forearm of the skeleton. Recall that the <button class='glossary-text'>head</button> of the radius articulates with the <button class='glossary-text'>capitulum</button> of the <button class='glossary-text'>humerus</button>. The <button class='glossary-text'>radial tuberosity</button> represents another point of attachment for the biceps. The proximal end of the ulna has a deep depression called the <button class='glossary-text'>trochlear notch</button> that articulates with the trochlea of the humerus. The trochlear notch is delineated by the <button class='glossary-text'>olecranon process</button> and the <button class='glossary-text'>coronoid process</button>. Note that the radius and ulna each have a distal protrusion called a <button class='glossary-text'>styloid process</button>, forming important points of attachment for <button class='glossary-text'>ligaments</button> of the wrist.

pageData.desc: Figure 11: Anterior views of the left radius and ulna
pageData.altText: Figure 11: Anterior views of the left radius and ulna

pageData.text: Three sets of bones comprise the wrist and hand: the of the wrist, the of the palm, and the phalanges (singular, ), or finger bones. The posterior surface of the left hand and wrist is shown in Figure 12. There are eight carpals: the and , which articulate with the ; the three-sided ; the pea-shaped ; the with its distinctive hook-shaped process; the large ; the four-sided ; and the , which articulates with the first metacarpal. The metacarpals are numbered I-V, with the first metacarpal at the base of the thumb. When you make a fist, the of the metacarpals are visible as the knuckles. The fingers are also numbered I-V, starting with the thumb. Each finger except for the thumb contains three phalanges: a , which articulates with the head of the metacarpal; a ; and a . The thumb contains only proximal and distal phalanges.

pageData.desc: Figure 12: Posterior view of the bones of the left hand and wrist
pageData.altText: Figure 12: Posterior view of the bones of the left hand and wrist

pageData.text: In Activity 5 you will identify the bones of the <button class='glossary-text'>pelvic girdle</button> and lower limbs using the human skeleton model.
During this activity, continue your search for at least one example of each of the five different classifications of bone based on shape. For each example, take a photograph.

pages.title: Activity 5
pages.pageTitle:
A
  The Appendicular Skeleton—The Pelvic Girdle and Lower Limb

pageData.text: The is formed by the two , or coxal (hip) bones, which join the and (singular, os coxae) of the to form the (see the frontal view of the pelvis, Figure 13). The pelvic girdle serves to attach the lower limbs to the and provides strong support for the upper body. Each os coxae is a composite bone, formed by the fusion during development of three separate bones: the , , and (see Figures 13 and 14).

pageData.desc: Figure 13: Frontal view of the pelvis
pageData.altText: Figure 13: Frontal view of the pelvis

pageData.desc: Figure 14: Lateral view of the os coxae
pageData.altText: Figure 14: Lateral view of the os coxae

pageData.text: Each <button class='glossary-text'>ilium</button> <button class='glossary-text'>articulates</button> with the <button class='glossary-text'>sacrum</button>, forming a <button class='glossary-text'>sacroiliac joint</button>. The wing-shaped, articulating portions of the ilium and sacrum are known as ala. The superior rim of each iliac ala is called an <button class='glossary-text'>iliac crest</button> and serves as an attachment point for multiple muscles of the torso, hips, and thighs. If you stand with your hands on your hips, your hands are resting on your iliac crests. The ilium has four projections, or spines, as shown in <button class='resource-text'>Figure 14</button>, lateral view. At the anterior edge of the iliac crest is the <button class='glossary-text'>anterior superior iliac spine</button>; at its posterior edge is the <button class='glossary-text'>posterior superior iliac spine</button>. Inferior to the projections are the anterior inferior iliac spine and the posterior inferior iliac spine. The spines are attachment points for muscles of the hip, trunk, and thigh. The internal surface of the ilium is largely occupied by a broad, shallow depression called the <button class='glossary-text'>iliac fossa</button>, a point of attachment for the iliacus muscle. The large indentation in the posterior of the ilium, just above the <button class='glossary-text'>ischium</button>, is the <button class='glossary-text'>greater sciatic notch</button>, named for a large nerve that passes through it.

The <button class='glossary-text'>ischium</button> is the most posterior and inferior region of the os coxae and is commonly called the sit-down bone. The most anterior region of the os coxae is the <button class='glossary-text'>pubis</button>. The two pubic bones meet anteriorly at a midline articulation called the <button class='glossary-text'>pubic symphysis</button> (or symphysis pubis), which is a cartilaginous, amphiarthotic joint. The angle between the inferior portions of the pubic bones is termed the <button class='glossary-text'>pubic arch</button>. The pubic arch tends to be broader and more curved in females than in males.

An examination of the pubis from a lateral viewpoint, as in Figure 14, reveals two bony branches, or <button class='glossary-text'>rami</button>: a <button class='glossary-text'>superior ramus</button> and an <button class='glossary-text'>inferior ramus</button>. The rami meet to form a prominence called the <button class='glossary-text'>pubic crest</button>. The pubic symphysis lies medial to the two pubic crests (shown from the frontal view in <button class='resource-text'>Figure 13</button>). The fusion of the pubis and ischium is interrupted by a large opening, the <button class='glossary-text'>obturator foramen</button>. In a living body, blood vessels and nerves pass through this opening.

The <button class='glossary-text'>acetabulum</button> is a cup-shaped depression located at the point of fusion of all three bones of the os coxae. It articulates with the <button class='glossary-text'>head</button> of the <button class='glossary-text'>femur</button>, or thigh bone, and is best viewed laterally, as in Figure 14.

The <button class='glossary-text'>femur</button>, or thigh bone, is the longest bone in the skeleton. An anterior view of the left femur is shown in Figure 15. Its knob-shaped <button class='glossary-text'>head</button> articulates with the <button class='glossary-text'>acetabulum</button> of the os coxae. A relatively narrow neck connects the head to the shaft of the femur. Just distal to the neck are two prominences: the more lateral <button class='glossary-text'>greater trochanter</button> and the more medial <button class='glossary-text'>lesser trochanter</button>. These are major points of muscle attachment. The <button class='glossary-text'>distal epiphysis</button> of the femur features key prominences: the <button class='glossary-text'>medial epicondyle</button> and the <button class='glossary-text'>lateral epicondyle</button>, and just distal and posterior to them, the <button class='glossary-text'>medial condyle</button> and the <button class='glossary-text'>lateral condyle</button>. The condyles articulate with the <button class='glossary-text'>tibia</button> of the lower leg, whereas the epicondyles are muscle attachment sites.

The <button class='glossary-text'>patellar surface</button> at the distal aspect of the femur articulates with the <button class='glossary-text'>patella</button>, or kneecap, a <button class='glossary-text'>sesamoid bone</button> involved in the attachment of thigh muscles. Figure 16 depicts the patella from the posterior.

image.altText: Figure 15: Anterior view of the left femur

image.desc: Figure 16: Posterior view of the patella
image.altText: Figure 16: Posterior view of the patella

desc: Figure 15: Anterior view of the left femur
Figure 16: Posterior view of the patella
altText: Figure 15: Anterior view of the left femur
Figure 16: Posterior view of the patella

pageData.text: The lower leg contains two bones: the larger and more medial <button class='glossary-text'>tibia</button>, or shin bone, and the more slender and lateral <button class='glossary-text'>fibula</button>, or calf bone. The left tibia and fibula are shown from the anterior aspect in Figure 17. The proximal end of the tibia features the medial and <button class='glossary-text'>lateral condyles</button>, which articulate with the distal end of the <button class='glossary-text'>femur</button>. Inferior to the condyles is the <button class='glossary-text'>tibial tuberosity</button>, a site of <button class='glossary-text'>ligament</button> and muscle attachment. The tibia and fibula articulate with one another at the proximal and distal tibiofibular joints. The <button class='glossary-text'>medial malleolus</button> of the tibia is a distal protrusion that is easily seen and palpated as the medial prominence of the ankle. The <button class='glossary-text'>lateral malleolus</button> of the fibula forms the lateral prominence of the ankle. Notice in <button class='resource-text'>Figure 4</button> that, of the two, only the tibia forms part of the knee joint and serves as a weight-bearing bone; the fibula does not. The fibula does, however, provide stability for the ankle.

pageData.desc: Figure 17: Anterior view of the left tibia and fibula
pageData.altText: Figure 17: Anterior view of the left tibia and fibula

pageData.text: The distal extremities of the <button class='glossary-text'>tibia</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>fibula</button> form part of the ankle. The remaining bones of the ankle and foot consist of seven <button class='glossary-text'>tarsals</button>: the <button class='glossary-text'>metatarsals</button> (numbered I-V, medial to lateral) and the <button class='glossary-text'>phalanges</button>. Figure 18 depicts the superior and lateral aspects of the left foot. The two largest tarsals, which bear the most weight, are the <button class='glossary-text'>calcaneus</button>, or heel bone, and the <button class='glossary-text'>talus</button>, which articulates with the calcaneus and the malleoli of the tibia and fibula. The remaining five tarsals are the <button class='glossary-text'>navicular</button>, the three <button class='glossary-text'>cuneiforms</button>, and the <button class='glossary-text'>cuboid</button>. Notice that the big toe contains only two phalanges, whereas the other toes each contain three.

pageData.desc: Figure 18: Bones of the left ankle and foot, shown from superior and lateral views
pageData.altText: Figure 18: Bones of the left ankle and foot, shown from superior and lateral views

pageData.text: In Activity 6 you will identify the types of <button class='glossary-text'>synovial joints</button> and the movements that occur at them using either the human skeleton model or yourself. You will take a photograph of at least one example of each type of synovial joint.

You have now examined most of the bones with their major surface features and now will turn to the types of joints, especially and the movements that occur at them. You may recall that synovial joints are , i.e., freely moveable joints. The various types of synovial joints are described in Table 2. Please note that not all of the joints listed are freely moveable on your skeleton model, so you may wish to locate them on yourself.
Take a photograph of at least one example of each type of joint (fibrous, cartilaginous and synovial), including 3 different examples of synovial joints listed in Table 2.

pageData.text: Certain standard terms are used to describe the different types of body movements (see Table 3).

tableData.text: Movement of two adjacent parts toward one another, decreasing the angle between the proximal and distal parts
Movement of two adjacent parts away from one another, increasing the angle between the proximal and distal parts
Movement of a body part away from the mid-line (of the body as a whole or a specific region of the body).
Movement of a body part toward the mid-line (of the body as a whole or a specific region of the body, such as a limb)
Movement of a body part around its own axis
Movement of a limb in a large circle, combining flexion, extension, abduction, and adduction
Inward rotation of the forearm and palm, or sole of foot
Outward rotation of the forearm and palm, or sole of foot
Tilting sole of foot toward midline of body
Tilting sole of foot away from midline of body
Foot extension at the ankle, moving dorsum (top) of the foot closer to the shin (anterior lower leg)
Foot flexion at the ankle, moving the sole (plantar region) of the foot downward, away from the back of the calf (posterior lower leg)
Movement in superior (upper) direction. For example,  bringing the lower jaw (mandible) toward the upper (maxilla)
Movement in an inferior (downward) direction. For example,  movement of the lower jaw (mandible) away from the upper (maxilla)
Grasping with thumb and opposing finger(s)

pageData.text: Figure 19 depicts examples of these different types of movements. Use it as a guide to replicate the movements using the skeleton, taking note of each joint that is involved. You may wish to replicate these movements yourself while looking in a full-length mirror.

Caution! If you experience pain or discomfort while replicating the movements shown in Figure 19 with your own body, stop immediately and work only with the skeleton. Seek medical attention if needed.

pageData.text: In Activity 7 you will create simulated muscles on the human skeleton model using tape and twine. You will take a photograph of each simulated muscle in its resting and contracted positions.

pages.title: Activity 7
pages.pageTitle:
A
  Muscle Origins, Insertions, and Actions

pageData.text: Now that you have investigated the skeleton and the range of joint movements, you will examine the , , and of selected skeletal muscles using twine and masking tape to simulate the muscles on your skeleton model. For each of the skeletal muscles listed in , you will attach one end of a length of twine to the designated muscle origin with a small piece of masking tape and the other end to the designated point of insertion. You may find it helpful to write O and I on the pieces of masking tape, representing the origin and insertion, respectively, of each muscle. Pulling on the middle of the twine will simulate muscle contraction, resulting in the characteristic action for the muscle. For example, the biceps brachii has an origin on the of the and another origin on the supraglenoid tubercle and the edge of the . Twine is taped to the coracoid process in Figure 20. The muscle’s insertion is on the . The simulated muscle is shown in its “relaxed” state, but pulling on the twine would result in the principal action of the biceps brachii, which is forearm flexion.
Your instructor may assign additional muscles for you to simulate.

pageData.text: Before proceeding, please note that, like the biceps (biceps brachii) and triceps (triceps brachii) of the upper arm discussed in the “Background” of this investigation (see ), many muscles have multiple origins and/or insertions. For purposes of this exercise, only one or two origins/insertions have been emphasized, and you may experiment by attaching your twine to any or all of them. Likewise, a muscle may work with others in a variety of different . Only the principal action is examined in this investigation.

pageData.text: Anatomists and health-care providers use specific terminology, such as proximal and distal, to ensure precise communication. Directional anatomical terms (see Table 5) describe the relative positions of body structures. Learning these terms is an essential part of the study of anatomy and physiology, so it is useful to familiarize yourself with them.

Keep in mind that all the terms in Table 5 refer to the body in the standard anatomical position: the body is upright, arms at the sides with palms of the hand forward. When referring to anatomical structures, always refer to the right or left side of the specimen or subject, not your own.

pageData.content: Table 3. Movements around synovial joints

tableData.text: Movement of two adjacent parts toward one another, decreasing the angle between the proximal and distal parts
Movement of two adjacent parts away from one another, increasing the angle between the proximal and distal parts
Movement of a body part away from the mid-line (of the body as a whole or a specific region of the body).
Movement of a body part toward the mid-line (of the body as a whole or a specific region of the body, such as a limb)
Movement of a body part around its own axis
Movement of a limb in a large circle, combining flexion, extension, abduction, and adduction
Inward rotation of the forearm and palm, or sole of foot
Outward rotation of the forearm and palm, or sole of foot
Tilting sole of foot toward midline of body
Tilting sole of foot away from midline of body
Foot extension at the ankle, moving dorsum (top) of the foot closer to the shin (anterior lower leg)
Foot flexion at the ankle, moving the sole (plantar region) of the foot downward, away from the back of the calf (posterior lower leg)
Movement in superior (upper) direction. For example,  bringing the lower jaw (mandible) toward the upper (maxilla)
Movement in an inferior (downward) direction. For example,  movement of the lower jaw (mandible) away from the upper (maxilla)
Grasping with thumb and opposing finger(s)

data.title: Acetabulum
data.content: A cup-shaped depression located at the point of fusion of all three bones of the os coxae

data.title: Acromion
data.content: An extension of the posterior scapular spine, articulates with the clavicle

data.title: Action
data.content: The movement that results when the muscle contracts

data.title: Agonist
data.content: The principal muscle that drives an action (prime mover)

data.title: Amphiarthoses
data.content: Slightly moveable joints, such as those between the vertebrae

data.title: Anatomical neck
data.content: Distal to the head of the humerus

data.title: Antagonist
data.content: A muscle whose action counteracts that of another specified muscle

data.title: Antagonistic muscle pair
data.content: One muscle contracts the other muscle relaxes or lengthens

data.title: Anterior superior iliac spine
data.content: The anterior edge of the iliac crest

data.title: Appendicular skeleton
data.content: Corresponds to the limbs, or appendages, and is composed of the bones of the arms, hands, fingers, legs, feet, and toes plus the structures that connect the limbs to the axial skeleton

data.title: Articulations (joints)
data.content: Regions that come together with adjacent bones

data.title: Atlas
data.content: First cervical vertebra

data.title: Axial skeleton
data.content: Corresponds roughly to the midline of the body and is composed of the skull, hyoid (not shown), vertebral column, ribs, and sternum

data.title: Axis
data.content: Second cervical vertebra

data.title: Body of the sternum
data.content: Main portion

data.title: Calcaneus
data.content: Heel bone

data.title: Capitate
data.content: A large bone in the wrist

data.title: Capitulum
data.content: Articulates with the head of the radius

data.title: Carpals
data.content: Wrist bones

data.title: Cartilage
data.content: A flexible connective tissue

data.title: Cartilaginous joint
data.content: Bones are joined with cartilage (fibrocartilage or hyaline cartilage), and the joint may be slightly but not freely moveable

data.title: Cervical vertebrae
data.content: Seven bones in the neck

data.title: Clavicle
data.content: Commonly known as the collarbone

data.title: Coccyx
data.content: Inferior to the sacrum, tail bone, composite bones, formed by the fusion of smaller, individual bones during development

data.title: Coracoid process
data.content: Important point of attachment for key muscles of the arm

data.title: Coronal suture
data.content: Where two parietal bones articulate with the frontal bone

data.title: Coronoid fossa
data.content: A depression just above  the trochlea and capitulum

data.title: Coronoid process
data.content: Delineates the trochlear notch

data.title: Costal cartilages
data.content: Composed of hyaline cartilage, allows for the vertebrosternal ribs to articulate anteriorly with the sternum

data.title: Cranium
data.content: Eight bones that form a protective dome or vault that encases the brain

data.title: Cuboid
data.content: One of the seven bones which make up the tarsus of the ankle and foot

data.title: Cuboid
data.content: Bones which make up the ankle and foot

data.title: Cuneiforms
data.content: Three of the seven bones which make up the tarsus of the ankle and foot

data.title: Cuneiforms
data.content: Bones which make up the ankle and foot

data.title: Deltoid tuberosity
data.content: An important surface feature that serves as a site of attachment for the deltoid muscle

data.title: Diaphysis (shaft)
data.content: Slender, elongated region on a typical long bone

data.title: Diarthoses
data.content: Freely moveable joints, such as the knee

data.title: Distal epiphysis
data.content: At the opposite end of the bone

data.title: Distal phalanx
data.content: One of three bones in the finger

data.title: Epiphyseal line
data.content: Between the epiphysis and metaphysis, remnant of the epiphyseal plate where the bone grew in length throughout childhood

data.title: Epiphysis (plural, epiphyses)
data.content: Expanded ends of a typical long bone

data.title: Ethmoid bone
data.content: Makes up the roof of the nasal cavity, the superior part of the nasal septum, and the medial portion of each orbit

data.title: Extensor
data.content: A muscle whose contraction extends or straightens a limb or other part of the body

data.title: External auditory meatus
data.content: Commonly known as the ear canal

data.title: External occipital protuberance
data.content: Projects from near the center of the occipital bone

data.title: Facial bones
data.content: There are 14, six pairs and two single bones

data.title: Femur
data.content: Thigh bone, is the longest bone in the skeleton

data.title: Fibrous joint
data.content: Bones are joined with dense connective tissue, and the joint is immoveable or slightly moveable

data.title: Fibula
data.content: Calf bone

data.title: Flat bone
data.content: Relatively thin and flat, like a plate

data.title: Flexor
data.content: A muscle that decrease the angle between bones on two sides of a joint

data.title: Foramen magnum
data.content: A large opening at the base of the skull

data.title: Frontal bone
data.content: This bone is the most anterior part of the cranium

data.title: Fulcrum
data.content: Fixed point on which a lever moves when force is applied

data.title: Glenohumeral joint
data.content: Shoulder joint

data.title: Glenoid cavity
data.content: Articulates with the humerus

data.title: Gomphosis (plural, gomphoses)
data.content: A specialized type of synarthosis, a tooth secured in its bony socket with fibrous connective tissue

data.title: Greater sciatic notch
data.content: Just above the ischium, named for a large nerve that passes through it

data.title: Greater trochanter
data.content: One of two bones distal to the neck of the femur

data.title: Greater tubercle
data.content: The upper lateral part of the end of the humerus

data.title: Hamate
data.content: Distinctive hook-shaped bone in the wrist

data.title: Head
data.content: Upper portion

data.title: Humerus
data.content: The only bone of the upper arm

data.title: Iliac crest
data.content: Serves as an attachment point for multiple muscles of the torso, hips, and thighs

data.title: Iliac fossa
data.content: A point of attachment for the iliacus muscle

data.title: Ilium
data.content: One of three bones that forms the hip

data.title: Inferior nasal conchae
data.content: Curved bones which form the lateral walls of the nasal cavity

data.title: Inferior ramus
data.content: One of two rami that meet to form a prominence called the pubic crest

data.title: Infraorbital foramen
data.content: An opening in the maxilla, serves as a passageway for blood vessels and nerves

data.title: Infraspinatous fossa
data.content: Inferior depression on the side of the spine

data.title: Insertion
data.content: The bone or other point of attachment (such as a tendon or other connective tissue) that tends to move the greatest distance when the muscle contracts

data.title: Intertubercular groove
data.content: Separate the greater tubercle and the lesser tubercle

data.title: Intervertebral discs
data.content: Fluid-filled fibrocartilaginous discs that separate vertebrae from one another

data.title: Irregular bone
data.content: Notably uneven in shape

data.title: Ischium
data.content: One of three bones that forms the hip

data.title: Joint cavity
data.content: Contains synovial fluid

data.title: Lacrimal
data.content: Very small bones located in the medial region of each orbit

data.title: Lambdoid suture
data.content: Where the two parietal bones articulate with the occipital bone

data.title: Lateral condyle
data.content: Articulate with the tibia of the lower leg

data.title: Lateral epicondyle
data.content: A prominence that flanks trochlea

data.title: Lateral epicondyle
data.content: On the lateral part of a long bone serving for the attachment of muscles and ligaments

data.title: Lateral malleolus
data.content: Forms the lateral prominence of the ankle

data.title: Lesser trochanter
data.content: One of two bones distal to the neck of the femur

data.title: Lesser tubercle
data.content: The lower part of the end of the humerus

data.title: Lever
data.content: A moveable, rigid bar

data.title: Ligament
data.content: Join bones to other bones

data.title: Long bone
data.content: Length of the bone is greater than its width, and both ends are expanded

data.title: Lumbar vertebrae
data.content: Five bones in the lower back

data.title: Lunate
data.content: Small bones in the wrist

data.title: Mandible
data.content: The largest bone in the human skull, located inferior to the maxilla

data.title: Manubrium of the sternum
data.content: Middle portion

data.title: Mastoid process
data.content: Posterior and inferior to the external auditory meatus, serves as a point of attachment for certain skeletal muscles of the head, neck, and back

data.title: Maxillae
data.content: Fused pair of maxilla bones makes up the upper jaw and contributes to the medial and inferior regions of the orbits

data.title: Medial condyle
data.content: Articulate with the tibia of the lower leg

data.title: Medial epicondyle
data.content: A prominence that flanks trochlea

data.title: Medial epicondyle
data.content: On the distal part of a long bone serving for the attachment of muscles and ligaments

data.title: Medial malleolus
data.content: A distal protrusion that is easily seen and palpated as the medial prominence of the ankle

data.title: Medullary cavity
data.content: Space within the diaphysis

data.title: Mental foramina
data.content: Two small lateral openings in the mandible

data.title: Mental protuberance
data.content: Forms the chin

data.title: Metacarpals
data.content: Palm bones

data.title: Metaphysis (plural, metaphyses)
data.content: Region between the diaphysis and each epiphysis

data.title: Metatarsals
data.content: Bones which make up the ankle and foot

data.title: Middle nasal conchae
data.content: Thin, scroll-shaped bony elements forming the upper chambers of the nasal cavities

data.title: Middle phalanx
data.content: One of three bones in the finger

data.title: Nasal bones
data.content: Form the bridge of the nose

data.title: Nasal septum
data.content: Mucosa-covered bony and cartilaginous structure located in the rough midline of the nose

data.title: Navicular
data.content: One of the seven bones which make up the tarsus of the ankle and foot

data.title: Navicular
data.content: Bones which make up the ankle and foot

data.title: Obturator foramen
data.content: A large opening that interrupts fusion of the pubis and ischium interrupted

data.title: Occipital bone
data.content: The most posterior bone of the cranium

data.title: Occipitomastoid sutures
data.content: Two sutures occur where the posterior and inferior region of each temporal bone articulates with the occipital bone

data.title: Olecranon process
data.content: Delineates the trochlear notch

data.title: Orbits
data.content: The cuplike depressions in which the eyeballs are located

data.title: Origin
data.content: Where the muscle is attached to the bone that has the greater mass and stability during contraction

data.title: Ossa coxae (coxal)
data.content: Hip bones, each is a composite bone, formed by the fusion during development of three separate bones: the ilium, ischium, and pubis

data.title: Parietal bones
data.content: Lie posterior to the frontal bone and comprise the right and left sides of the cranium

data.title: Patella
data.content: Kneecap, a sesamoid bone involved in the attachment of thigh muscles

data.title: Patellar surface
data.content: The distal aspect of the femur articulates with the patella

data.title: Pectoral girdle
data.content: Consists of the clavicles and scapulae (shoulder blades) and joins the arms to the axial skeleton

data.title: Pectoral girdles
data.content: Serve to attach the arms to the axial skeleton by means of attached skeletal muscles

data.title: Pelvic girdle
data.content: Consists of the ossa coxae (singular, os coxae), or hip bones, which join the legs to the axial skeleton

data.title: Pelvic girdle
data.content: Formed by the two ossa coxae, or coxal (hip) bones, which join the sacrum and coccyx (singular, os coxae) of the vertebral column to form the pelvis

data.title: Pelvis
data.content: Area of the body below the abdomen that is located between the hip bones

data.title: Phalanges
data.content: Bones which make up the ankle and foot

data.title: Phalanx (plural, phalanges)
data.content: Finger bones

data.title: Pisiform
data.content: Pea-shaped bone in the wrist

data.title: Posterior superior iliac spine
data.content: Posterior edge of the iliac crest

data.title: Proximal epiphysis
data.content: Closest to the center of the body of a bone

data.title: Proximal phalanx
data.content: One of three bones in the finger, articulates with the head of the metacarpal

data.title: Pubic arch
data.content: Angle between the inferior portions of the pubic bones

data.title: Pubic crest
data.content: Where two rami meet

data.title: Pubic symphysis (symphysis pubis)
data.content: A cartilaginous, amphiarthrotic joint

data.title: Pubis
data.content: One of three bones that forms the hip

data.title: Radial tuberosity
data.content: Point of attachment for the biceps

data.title: Radius
data.content: Lateral long bone of the forearm

data.title: Rami
data.content: Two bony branches meet to form a prominence called the pubic crest

data.title: Red marrow
data.content: A type of bone marrow in which stem cells that generate blood cells reside

data.title: Sacroiliac joint
data.content: Where each ilium articulates with the sacrum

data.title: Sacrum
data.content: Inferior to the last lumbar vertebra

data.title: Sagittal suture
data.content: Where the two parietal bones articulate with one another, at the superior midline of the cranium

data.title: Scaphoid
data.content: Cashew-shaped bone in the wrist

data.title: Scapula
data.content: Commonly known as the shoulder blade, is a wing-shaped bone

data.title: Sesamoid bone
data.content: Embedded in a tendon at a joint

data.title: Short bone
data.content: Length and width of the bone are roughly the same, making the shape somewhat cubelike

data.title: Sphenoid bone
data.content: Posterior region of each orbit

data.title: Squamosal sutures
data.content: Where the articulation of a parietal bone with a temporal bone

data.title: Sternum
data.content: Commonly called the breastbone, a composite bone with three components

data.title: Styloid process
data.content: A distal protrusion, important parts of attachment the radius and ulna

data.title: Subscapular fossa
data.content: Flattened anterior side of the scapula

data.title: Superior nasal conchae
data.content: Thin, scroll-shaped bony elements forming the upper chambers of the nasal cavities

data.title: Superior ramus
data.content: One of two rami that meet to form a prominence called the pubic crest

data.title: Supraorbital foramen
data.content: A small opening above each orbit

data.title: Supraspinatous fossa
data.content: A superior depression on the side of the spine

data.title: Surgical neck
data.content: Distal to the anatomical neck

data.title: Sutures
data.content: Where the bones of the cranium articulate

data.title: Synarthoses
data.content: Immoveable joints, such as the sutures that join the bones of the cranium

data.title: Synovial joint
data.content: Hyaline cartilage–covered ends of the bones are separated by a joint cavity filled with lubricating synovial fluid, the joint is freely moveable

data.title: Synovial membrane
data.content: Produces synovial fluid

data.title: Talus
data.content: Articulates with the calcaneus and the malleoli of the tibia and fibula

data.title: Tarsals
data.content: Bones which make up the ankle and foot

data.title: Temporal bones
data.content: Lie inferior to the parietal bones and make up the lateral aspect of the cranium

data.title: Temporomandibular joint
data.content: Lower jawbone articulates with the temporal bone in the only diarthosis of the skull

data.title: Tendon
data.content: Join muscle to bone

data.title: Thoracic cage
data.content: Composed of the ribs, sternum, and thoracic vertebrae

data.title: Thoracic vertebrae
data.content: Twelve bones in the upper back

data.title: Tibia
data.content: Shin bone

data.title: Tibial tuberosity
data.content: A site of ligament and muscle attachment

data.title: Trapezium
data.content: Four-sided bone in the wrist

data.title: Trapezoid
data.content: Four-sided bone in the wrist

data.title: Triquetral
data.content: Three-sided bone in the wrist

data.title: Trochlea
data.content: Meets the ulna of the forearm

data.title: Trochlear notch
data.content: A deep depression that articulates with the trochlea of the humerus

data.title: Ulna
data.content: Medial long bone of the forearm

data.title: Vertebral column
data.content: Also known as the spine or backbone, is a set of 26 bones extending from the base of the skull to the pelvis

data.title: Vertebral ribs (floating ribs)
data.content: Two pairs fond at the inferior region of the thoracic cage

data.title: Vertebrocostal ribs
data.content: Three pairs of vertebrocostal ribs that articulate with the costal cartilages located just above them

data.title: Vertebrosternal ribs
data.content: Superior seven pairs of ribs

data.title: Vomer
data.content: Unpaired bone is medially situated within the nasal cavity

data.title: Xiphoid process
data.content: Inferior to the body of the sternum

data.title: Yellow marrow
data.content: A type of bone marrow that is rich in fat cells

data.title: Zygomatic bone
data.content: Lies lateral to a maxilla, the cheekbones
